I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

 
1. 
I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan of 
up  to  B1,500,000,000  (or  its  equivalent  in  United  States  dollars)  to  Energy  Absolute  Public 
Company  Limited  for  the  Green  Loan  for  Renewable  Energy  and  Electric  Vehicle  Charging 
Network in Thailand. 
 
The project entails a corporate loan with a 3-year tenor to support the ongoing renewable 
2. 
energy and sustainable transport activities of Energy Absolute Public Company Limited (Energy 
Absolute). The loan will be used to finance two of Energy Absolute’s operating solar and wind 
projects  in  Thailand  (the  Nakornsawan  Solar  Power  Project  and  the  Hanuman  Wind  Power 
Project), as well as Energy Absolute’s ongoing investment in a comprehensive electric vehicle 
charging network (EVCN) in Thailand. This green loan1 is expected to be the first certified climate 
loan  in  Thailand2 and  one  of  the  first  in  Asia.  The  assistance  of  the  Asian  Development  Bank 
(ADB) will support Thailand’s renewable energy sector, increase awareness about green loans, 
and support the transition from a conventional automotive industry to an electric vehicle industry 
in  Thailand  by  establishing  a  comprehensive  EVCN  across  Thailand’s  major  cities.  ADB’s 
assistance  will  also  support  a  leading  clean  energy  and  sustainable  transport  company  in 
Thailand at a time when capital markets are still adjusting to the ongoing disruptions caused by 
the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic. 
 

II. 

THE PROJECT 

Project Identification and Description 

 
A. 
 
3. 
Project identification. ADB has built strong relationships with key participants in the Thai 
energy and transport sectors since 2009. ADB supported Energy Absolute’s maiden green bond 
issuance  in  2019,3 and  has  been  discussing the company’s  ongoing  sustainable  transport  and 
clean energy plans. Energy Absolute is a climate and green investment leader in the region and 
the company sees ADB as a valuable partner to support their strategy. Energy Absolute’s strategy 
is  strongly  aligned  with  Thailand’s  industrial,  climate  and  electric  mobility  targets,  and  ADB’s 
Strategy 2030 commitments to climate mitigation.4 CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION DELETED. 
 
4. 
ADB has increased its efforts to promote green financial instruments, such as green bonds 
and  loans.  Green  loans  help  to  provide  a  mechanism  for  financing  investments  in  green  and 
climate-smart  projects  that  are  aligned  with  the  Paris  Agreement  on  climate  change  and  the 
United Nations’ 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development. The Green Loan Principles5 (GLP) 
support  the  promotion  of  environmentally  sustainable  lending  practices.  Green  loans  can  be 
certified as climate loans under the Climate Bonds Standard and Certification Scheme (footnote 
2) which is the most prominent labelling scheme for green bonds and green loans globally, and 
is designed to be consistent with the goals of the Paris Agreement to limit global warming to well 
under 2°C. 

 

1  A  green  loan  is  a  loan  used  to  finance  or  re-finance,  in  whole  or  in  part,  new  and/or  existing  projects  with 

environmental benefits. Climate loans are focused on climate change benefits in particular. 

2  Certified by the Climate Bonds Initiative. https://www.climatebonds.net/certification. 
3  ADB. Thailand. Energy Absolute Green Bond for Wind Power Project. 
4  ADB. 2018. Strategy 2030: Achieving a Prosperous, Inclusive, Resilient, and Sustainable Asia and the Pacific. Manila. 
5  The  Green  Loan  Principles  were  developed  by  the  Loan  Market  Association,  the  Asia  Pacific  Loan  Market 
Association and the Loan Syndications and Trading Association, based on the Green Bond Principles developed by 
the International Capital Market Association. 

 2

 

 
5. 
Although the global market for green bonds has grown rapidly, green loans have remained 
a relatively less well-known instrument. The project will contribute to the greening of Thailand’s 
finance markets by showcasing international best practice approaches to green loan verification 
and certification. This green loan is expected to be the first certified climate loan in Thailand. 
 
6. 
ADB’s  Private  Sector  Operations  Department  has  been  increasing  its  focus  on  sectors 
other  than  energy.  Transport  is  typically  a  significant  contributor  to  greenhouse  gas  (GHG) 
emissions.  The  transport  sector  makes  up  around  26%  of  Thailand’s  annual  GHG  emissions. 
Electrification of vehicles and decarbonization of the transport sector are widely seen as a critical 
challenge to meet commitments made under the Paris Agreement. Electric vehicles can help to 
reduce transport sector GHG emissions while reducing local air pollution. Thailand is aiming to 
become a regional leader in electric vehicles with long-term targets to substantially increase the 
number of electric vehicles on Thailand’s roads and expand public charging infrastructure. 
 
7. 
Project description. The Project entails a corporate loan of up to B1.5 billion with a 3-
year  tenor  to  support  Energy  Absolute’s  ongoing  renewable  energy  and  sustainable  transport 
activities during a time when the company faces increased uncertainty with debt raising due to 
COVID-19. The loan will be used for the financing of two of Energy Absolute’s operating solar and 
wind projects in Thailand (the Nakornsawan Solar Power Project and the Hanuman Wind Power 
Project),  as  well  as  Energy  Absolute’s  ongoing  efforts  to  establish  a  comprehensive  EVCN  in 
Thailand. Thailand has long-term ambitions to be an electric vehicle hub of Southeast Asia and 
Energy Absolute is positioning itself to be a leader in this sector, with plans to develop battery and 
electric vehicle manufacturing capacity as well as a comprehensive EVCN in Thailand comprising 
at least 3,600 charging stations by 2023. 
 
8. 
Borrower. Energy Absolute was established in 2006 and is the largest renewable energy 
company in Thailand by installed capacity. Its main businesses are renewable energy generation 
(solar  and  wind),  and  biodiesel  production  and  distribution.  Energy  Absolute  is  expanding  into 
other  clean  energy  and  sustainable  transport  growth  opportunities,  such  as  (i)  production  of 
lithium-ion  batteries  for  transport  and  power;  (ii)  electric  cars  and  ferries,  including  associated 
charging infrastructure; (iii) development of new renewable energy projects outside of Thailand, 
and renewable energy projects with integrated battery energy storage systems; and (iv) "green 
biodiesel"6 and phase change materials. Mr. Somphote Ahunai, the founder and chief executive 
officer, is the major shareholder holding a 43.68% stake together with his family members. UBS 
AG Singapore Branch holds another 10.96% of shares as custodian and nominee shareholder. 
Energy Absolute is listed on the Stock Exchange of Thailand and as of 21 July 2020 has a market 
capitalization of B187.4 billion. 
 
9. 
As of June 2020, Energy Absolute has six renewable power plants in operation, with a 
total capacity of 664 megawatts (MW)—four solar power (278 MW) and two wind power (386 MW) 
plants. All renewable energy plants have long-term power purchase agreements with Electricity 
Generating  Authority  of  Thailand  and  the  Provincial  Electricity  Authority.  Table  1  summarizes 
Energy  Absolute’s  renewable  energy  portfolio.  The  proposed  project  will  support  the  financing 
and continued operation of the Nakornsawan and Hanuman renewable energy projects. 
 

6  Green  biodiesel,  also  known  as  renewable  diesel  or  second-generation  diesel,  is  derived  from  biomass  and  can 

result in lower lifetime emissions from engines that run on diesel fuel.

Technologies Inc., a Taipei,China manufacturer of lithium-ion polymer batteries for use in electric 
vehicles  and  stationary  energy  storage.  In  2019,  Energy  Absolute  also  began  building  a  1

12. 
Energy Absolute’s financial performance is strong, with 12.7% cumulative average growth 
in  revenue  and  continuously  improving  profitability  during  2016–2019,  as  shown  by  annual 
improvements in earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortization; operating cash 
flow;  and  net  profit.  Nearly  all  growth  in  revenue  and  profitability  results  from  the  successful 
commissioning of multiple renewable power projects, notably the Phitsanulok solar plant in 2016 
(90 MW), the  Hadkanghan  wind farm  in  2017  (126  MW),  and  the  Hanuman  wind  farm  in  April 
2019 (260 MW). The company’s revenue and profit are expected to further increase in 2020 due 
to  the  full-year  contribution  of  the  Hanuman  project.  Table  2  summarizes  Energy  Absolute’s 
historical consolidated financial performance.

13. 
ADB conducted integrity and enhanced tax integrity due diligence on Energy Absolute, its 
board  of  directors, shareholders, and  managers.7 CONFIDENTIAL  INFORMATION DELETED. 
Having reviewed the proposed green bond transaction, ADB does not believe that the transaction 
was established or is  being used for cross-border tax evasion, money laundering, or terrorism 
financing in the jurisdictions involved in the project. 
 
14. 
Impact of COVID-19 pandemic. The COVID-19 pandemic has not had a direct material 
impact  on  the  projects  this  proposed  loan  will  support.  However,  the  pandemic  has  caused 
increased  uncertainty  regarding  Energy  Absolute’s  ongoing  capital  raising  efforts,  which  led 
Energy  Absolute  to  seek  ADB  assistance  for  a  portion  of  their  2020  financing  requirements. 
Although the COVID-19 pandemic is not expected to impact project costs or implementation, the 
continued operation and viability of Thailand’s renewable energy power projects, and investment 
into a comprehensive EVCN, will help ensure Thailand’s continued progress towards its long-
term emissions reduction targets. 
 
B. 
 
15. 
Impacts. The project is aligned with the following impacts: (i) Thailand’s finance sector 
becomes more green,8 and (ii) Thailand’s automotive industry transitioned to an electric vehicle 
industry.9 
 
16. 
Outcome.  The  project’s  outcome  is  sustainable  funding  of  business  expansion  and 
continuity  of  Energy  Absolute’s  clean  energy  investments  enabled.  This  includes  a  green  loan 
certified  as  a  climate  loan  by  the  Climate  Bonds  Initiative,  underscoring  the  company’s 
commitment to sustainability. 
 
Outputs.  The  project  will  have  the  following  outputs:  (i)  establishment  of  an  EVCN 
17.

renewable energy projects achieved, and (iii) gender equality improved.

Alignment with ADB Strategy and Operations 

C. 
 
18. 
Consistency with ADB strategy and country strategy. The project is consistent with 
ADB’s Strategy 2030, which targets that 75% of ADB operations should support climate change 
mitigation and adaptation by 2030, and that ADB assistance for climate finance total $80 billion 
during  2019–2030  (footnote  4).  ADB’s  Strategy  2030  also  promotes  the  expansion  of  private 
sector operations into sustainable transport and urban transport. ADB’s support for the project is 
also in line with its country partnership strategy (2013–2016),10 and country operations business 
plan  (2020–2022) 11  for  Thailand,  which  promote  private  sector  development,  infrastructure 
development,  and  environmentally  sustainable  development.  The  proposed  project  also  aligns 
with the forthcoming country partnership strategy 2021–2025 for Thailand, which will emphasize 
sustainable and resilient growth, and the role of non-sovereign operations. 
 
19. 
Consistency  with  sector  strategy  and  relevant  ADB  operations.  The  project  is 
consistent with ADB’s Energy Policy, which supports wider access to energy through investments 
in energy efficiency and renewable energy projects.12 
 
20. 
Lessons  from  previous  operations.  ADB’s  private  sector  operations  department  has 
supported  a  number  of  renewable  energy  projects  and  climate  aligned  financings  in  Thailand, 
including ADB’s first loan to Energy Absolute for the Energy Absolute Green Bond for Wind Power 
Project in 2019 (footnote 3).13 ADB can play a valuable role in assisting with the certification of 
green  financial  products  such  as  loans  and  bonds.  ADB’s  involvement  in  such  projects  can 
provide strong market validation and help increase awareness of climate aligned investments. As 
ADB’s first private sector EVCN investment, the project will also contribute to important lessons 
for future electric mobility opportunities across Asia and the Pacific. 
 
D.

Arrangements 
Energy  Absolute’s  solar  and  wind  power  plants  are  developed  under  Thailand’s  SPP 
program, which allows private developers to build, own, and operate energy power projects 
of 10–90 MW capacity and to enter into PPAs with EGAT. 
The  installation  of  electric  vehicle  charging  stations  requires  approval  from  the  Energy 
Regulatory Commission under Energy Industry Act B.E. 2550. 
Energy Absolute’s senior management consists of experienced professionals with extensive 
managerial  and  technical  knowledge  in  renewable  energy  and  finance.  As  of  May  2020, 
Energy Absolute’s management has overseen the successful development and operation of 
six renewable energy plants with a total installed capacity of 664 MW. It is also developing 
a  lithium-ion  battery  factory  in  Thailand,  electric  cars,  electric  ferries,  and  associated 
charging infrastructure. 
Energy  Absolute  sells  electricity  to  EGAT  under  the  SPP  program.  Revenue  is  fully 
contracted,  with  long-term  PPAs  with  creditworthy  offtakers.  Energy  Absolute’s  electric 
vehicle  charging  stations are  located  in prime  locations  in  partnership  with various major 
partners, mostly in malls, residential estates, office buildings, hospitals, convenience stores, 
and gas stations. CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION DELETED

Energy Absolute’s green loan will be certified as a climate loan under the CBS and will also 
adhere to the GLP. To obtain CBS certification, the underlying projects must comply with 
the relevant sector criteria. For this project, it is expected that the financing will comply with 
the following sector criteria under the CBS; low carbon transport; solar energy; wind energy. 
To maintain climate loan certification under the CBS, the company will need to provide an 
annual monitoring report to (i) confirm that it has not disposed of or otherwise refinanced the 
underlying  asset  and  (ii)  present  the  operational  performance  of  the  projects  such  as 
megawatt-hours  of  renewable  energy  generation  delivered  or  total  kWh  of  electricity 
provided through the charging network. 
The  company  will  submit  quarterly  unaudited  financial  statements  and  annual  audited 
financial statements on a consolidated basis.

The Assistance 

 
A. 
 
25. 
ADB  will  provide  debt  financing  to  Energy  Absolute  in  the  form  of  a  non-amortizing 
corporate loan of up to B1.5 billion (or its equivalent in United States dollars) with a 3-year tenor 
and  a  bullet  repayment.  ADB’s  assistance  will  support  the  financing  and  operation  of  two  of 
Energy Absolute’s renewable power projects and the establishment of a comprehensive EVCN in

 7 

Value Added by ADB Assistance 

Thailand. ADB will also ensure that the loan will be recognized as a certified climate loan. This is 
expected to be the first Climate Bonds Initiative certified climate loan in Thailand from only the 
second issuer of a certified climate loan in Asia. 
 
B. 
 
26. 
ADB’s participation in the transaction will ensure that the loan will comply with the Green 
Loan Principles (footnote 5) and will be certified by the Climate Bonds Initiative under the Climate 
Bonds Standard and Certification Scheme as a climate loan (footnote 2). Green loans are even 
less  well  recognized  than  green  bonds,  and  ADB’s  support  will  help  make  the  climate  finance 
benefits of certified climate loans better known in the region. Obtaining climate loan certification 
will help contribute to greater awareness of the potential to align the finance sector with the Paris 
Agreement,  and  the  United  Nations’  2030  Agenda  for  Sustainable  Development.  ADB’s 
assistance will support the continued operation of Energy Absolute’s existing renewable energy 
power projects, which provide zero GHG-emission electricity to the Thai grid. This is especially 
important  during  a  highly  uncertain  time  in  which  the  company  is  facing  increased  uncertainty 
raising debt and is seeking to diversify funding sources. ADB’s assistance will also support the 
implementation  of  what  will  be  one  of  Southeast  Asia’s  largest  EVCNs.  Energy  Absolute’s 
environmental  and  social  management  system  (ESMS)  complies  with  ADB  standards  and  will 
promote higher standards for the supported projects. 
 
27. 
Support during COVID-19 pandemic. ADB’s involvement will help Energy Absolute at a 
time  when  financial markets  and  banks  are  adjusting to  the ongoing  impacts  of the  COVID-19 
pandemic. The pandemic has caused increased uncertainty for Energy Absolute’s capital raising. 
 
28. 
Electric  vehicle  charging  network.  The  project  will  be  the  first  investment  by  ADB’s 
Private Sector Operations Department to support the establishment of a comprehensive EVCN. 
Electrification of vehicles and decarbonization of the transport sector is widely seen as a critical 
objective to meet the commitments made under the Paris Agreement. Even if charged using a 
grid that uses power generated from fossil fuels, electric vehicles can still reduce GHG-emissions 
compared  to  internal  combustion  engine  vehicles.  In  addition,  fully  battery  powered  electric 
vehicles do not produce local exhaust pipe air pollutants (e.g. carbon monoxide, lead, ground-
level  ozone,  particulate  matter,  sulfur  dioxide,  and  nitrogen  dioxide).  ADB’s  involvement  will 
significantly enhance market awareness of Thailand’s activities in the electric vehicle sector and 
demonstrate  the  role  high-level  technology  can  play  in  the  urban  transport  sector  for  ADB’s 
developing member countries.
